{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} '''John William Earnshaw''' (1900–82) was a self-taught [[Australian]] [[engineer]], and [[inventor]]. He also conducted research into [[Australian history]].<ref>Russell, Eric (1983). The modest engineer. Biblionews, 8(1), p. 12–15.</ref>
Earnshaw was born in [[Randwick, New South Wales]], the son of a noted [[Sydney]] [[horse trainer]] and [[Melbourne Cup]] winner. He served with the [[Royal Engineers]] in [[France]] during [[World War I]]. After the war, Earnshaw undertook many dangerous travels in [[Papua New Guinea]].
Earnshaw set up a business, Reilax Engineering, which specialised in [[production-line]] problems. The business prospered for over 30 years in [[North Sydney, New South Wales]], until he retired in 1969. He invented a number of machines for filling metal and glass containers for the food, [[cosmetics]], chemical and [[pharmaceutical]] manufacturing industries. For the Red Cross Blood Bank, Earnshaw devised an [[oscillator]] for separating [[Blood plasma|plasma]] from blood. He was a pioneer of industrial [[chromium plating]] in Sydney. His oil-free compressor was widely used on tractors, [[grader]]s, [[road roller]]s and similar [[earthmoving equipment]].
Earnshaw's spare time was filled with research into forgotten aspects of Australian history, uncovering new information about the [[Scottish Martyrs]],<ref>Earnshaw, John (1959). Thomas Muir: Scottish martyr [Studies in Australian and Pacific History, no 1 (W. W. Stone, editor)]. Cremorne, NSW: Stone Copying Company.</ref> judge-advocate David Collins, early Sydney [[cabinetmaker]]s,<ref>Earnshaw, John (1971). Early Sydney cabinetmakers 1804 – 1870: A directory with an introductory survey. Sydney: Wentworth Books. {{ISBN|0855870028}}</ref> and John George Lang – the first Australian [[short story]] writer. He authored several biographies for the [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]].
In 1944, Earnshaw was a co-founder of the [[Book Collectors Society of Australia]], and a lifelong supporter of the society. He was also very active in the [[Society of Australian Genealogists]].

{{Other uses|Timnath (disambiguation){{!}}Timnath}} {{Infobox ancient site |name = Khirbet et-Tibbaneh |native_name = תמנה |alternate_name = Tibna / Timnah |image = File:Khirbet et-Tibbaneh - 3.jpg |alt = |caption = View of stone structures ''in situ'' |map_type = Israel |map_alt = |map_size = 150 |location = {{flagicon|Israel}} |region = Judaean Mountains |coordinates = {{coord|31|41|40|N|35|02|40|E|type:city_region:IL|display=inline,title}} |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = Canaanite period |abandoned = unknown |epochs = Late Iron II, Hellenistic, Roman |cultures = Canaanite, Jewish, Greco-Roman |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = none |archaeologists = |condition = Ruin |ownership = |public_access = |website = |notes = }} '''Khirbet et-Tibbâneh''' (''Hurvat Tibneh'' / ''Kh. Tibna'')({{lang-ar|خربة التبانة}}),<ref>In the 1928–1947 Jaffa:Survey of Palestine map published by the [[National Library of Israel]], [http://web.nli.org.il/sites/nli/hebrew/digitallibrary/pages/viewer.aspx?presentorid=NLI_MAPS_JER&DocID=NNL_MAPS_JER002367636#|FL21693604 See Map], Map no. 15-12 (at Grid number 154/122) is called ''Kh. et Tabbâna'', but in the [[Survey of Western Palestine|SWP]] Map number 17 published by the [[Palestine Exploration Fund]], the same site is called ''Tibna''.</ref> sometimes referred to by [[historical geographers]] as the '''''Timnah of Judah''''' ({{Lang-he-n|'''תמנה'''}}), is a small ruin situated on a high ridge in the [[Judaean Mountains|Judaean mountains]], in the ''Sansan Nature Reserve'', {{convert|622|m|ft|}} above sea level, about 3 kilometers east of [[Aviezer]] and ca. 7 kilometers southeast of [[Bayt Nattif]]. The site is thought to have formerly borne the name Timnath, distinct from the [[Timnah|Tel Batash-Timnah]] site associated with the biblical story of [[Samson]] in the lower foothills of Judea along the [[Nahal Sorek|Sorek valley]]. ''Kh. et-Tibbaneh'' (Timnah) is perched upon a high mountain ridge rising up from the [[Elah valley]] and is where the episode of [[Judah (son of Jacob)|Judah]] and [[Tamar (Genesis)|Tamar]] is thought to have taken place.
==Etymology== Orientalists, [[Clermont-Ganneau]] and [[Edward Robinson (scholar)|Edward Robinson]], have made a point in showing the etymological Hebrew origins of certain Arabic place-names, saying that the Hebrew place-name Timnah was to be recognised in the Arabic corruption, ''Tibneh'' or ''Tibna''.<ref>Charles Simon Clermont-Ganneau, ''Archaeological Researches in Palestine During the Years 1873–1874'' (vol. II), [[Palestine Exploration Fund]]: London 1896, pp. 67–68, 214, where he wrote: (p. 214) "''Tibneh'', 'chopped straw', one would swear was Arabic, but it is beyond a doubt that it is the name of the town ''Timnah'', brought into that shape by one of those popular etymologies which are as dear to the peasantry of Palestine as to those of our European countries." On pp. 67–68 he wrote: "One has to beware, however, of these appellations that appear to be of purely Arabic origin, they are often ancient Hebrew names converted by a process of popular etymology into words familiar to the Arabs. In many cases slight phonetic changes assist the process. These , by the bye, are not arbitrary, but are subject to real laws. Thus, for instance, the name of the Bible town of Thimnah has become in [[Peasant|fellâh]] speech ''Tibneh'', 'chopped straw'."</ref><ref>Edward Robinson, ''Biblical Researches in Palestine and in the Adjacent Regions'', II, Boston 1860, p. 17</ref> [[John William McGarvey]] (1881) who quotes [[C. R. Conder|Conder]] on the linguistic evidence of the name says that, in Arabic, "the substitution of B for M is so common (as in Tibneh for [[Timnah]])..."<ref>McGarvey, 2002, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UxlR49W76CgC&pg=PA246 246-247]</ref><ref>[[E. H. Palmer]], ''The Survey of Western Palestine: Arabic and English Name Lists Collected During the Survey'', London 1881, p. [https://archive.org/stream/surveyofwesternp00conduoft#page/330 330], s.v. ''Tibna''</ref> Both names have been preserved in the respective sites.
==Site and identification== In ancient Jewish classical literature, two distinct sites in the land of Judah bore the name Timnath (Timnah).<ref>A. Neubauer, ''Géographie du Talmud'', Paris 1868, pp. 102–103; Isaiah Press (ed.), ''A Topographical - Historical Encyclopedia of Palestine'' (vol. 4), Rubin Mass: Jerusalem 1955, p. 974 (s.v. '''תמנה א''')</ref><ref name=EncyclopaediaJudaica1971>''[[Encyclopaedia Judaica]]'' (vol. 15), Jerusalem 1971, p. 1147 (s.v. Timnah)</ref> The [[Book of Joshua]] records the names of two towns, both in the tribal inheritance of Judah and having the identical name of Timnath; the one Timnath <small>(Josh. 15:10)</small> being transcribed alongside the name of [[Beit Shemesh]], while the other Timnath <small>(Josh. 15:57)</small> being transcribed alongside the name of Gibeah (of Judah), a town said to be [[Jab'a]].<ref>An opinion expressed by [[Historical geography|historical geographer]] [[Samuel Klein (scholar)|Samuel Klein]], ''Eretz Yehudah'' (the Land of Judah), Tel-Aviv 1939, p. 198, and by [[Palestine Exploration Fund|PEF]] explorers Conder and Kitchener (SWP, III, 53). Jab'a, southeast of [[Bayt Nattif]], is not far situated from ''Khirbet et-Tibbaneh''.</ref> The [[Jerusalem Talmud]] (''Sotah'' 1:8) relates the following tradition: "[[Abba Arika|Rav]] has said: There were two Timnaths; one mentioned in connection with [[Judah (son of Jacob)|Judah]], and the other mentioned in connection with [[Samson]]."<ref>Same quote cited in [[Midrash Rabba]] (Genesis Rabba § 85 and Numbers Rabba 9:24) and in the Babylonian Talmud (Sotah 10a). The 14th-century [[Midrash Hagadol]] brings down this tradition under a variant name: "[[Judah ha-Nasi|Rebbe]] has said," etc., instead of "Rav has said."</ref> The Talmudic exegetes have explained that Samson, who lived in the hilltop town of [[Zorah]] near Beit Shemesh, is said to have 'gone down' to Timnath,<ref>[https://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0714.htm Judges 14:1]</ref> but Judah is said to have 'gone up' to Timnath.<ref>[https://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0138.htm#13 Genesis 38:13]</ref> ''Kh. et-Tibbâneh'' is thought to be the Timnath (Timnah) mentioned in connection with Judah and Tamar <small>(Genesis 38: 13, 14)</small>,<ref>See [[George L. Kelm]] & [[Amihai Mazar]], p. 58 in: {{cite journal |last=Kelm |first=George |title=Timnah: A Biblical City in the Sorek Valley |journal=Archaeology |accessdate=20 August 2018 |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=58-59, 78-79|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/41729127 |date=1984|registration=yes |via=[[JSTOR]]}}</ref><ref>[[F.M Abel|F.M. Abel]], ''Géographie de la Palestine'' (vol. II), Paris 1938, p. 481, s.v. Thimna (1), citing Conder & Kitchener's SWP, III, p. 53.</ref><ref>[[Samuel Klein (scholar)|Samuel Klein]], ''Eretz Yisrael: Geography of Israel for High Schools and for the People'' (Heb. ארץ ישראל -- גיאוגרפיה של ארץ ישראל לבתי ספר תיכוניים ולעם), Vienna 1922, p. 42 (Hebrew)</ref> although this view remains inconclusive.<ref name=EncyclopaediaJudaica1971 /><ref>[[H.B. Tristram]], ''Bible Places: or, The Topography of the Holy Land: a Succinct Account of All the Places, Rivers, and Mountains of the Land of Israel'', London 1897, p. [https://archive.org/stream/bibleplacesortop00tris#page/66/mode/2up 66]. who thought that it was one and the same place, where Samson had gone to take his wife, near the Sorek Valley.</ref>
''Khirbet et Tibbaneh'' (''Tibna'') was visited by [[Palestine Exploration Fund]] explorers, [[C. R. Conder|Conder]] and [[HH Kitchener|Kitchener]], in the late 19th-century, where they described the ruin as follows: "Timnah - A town of Judah <small>(Josh. XV. 57)</small>, mentioned with Gibeah. There is a ruin called ''Tibna'' near [[Jab'a|Jeb'a]], in the higher hills of ʾArkûb, distinct from Tibneh <small>(Sheet XVI)</small>, which represents the Timnah of Joshua XV.10."<ref>Conder & Kitchener, ''Survey of Western Palestine - Memoirs of the Topography, Orography, Hydrography, and Archaeology'' (vol. III), London 1883, p. [https://archive.org/stream/surveyofwesternp03conduoft#page/52 53]</ref>
Others are unsure of its identification, since the site has yet to be fully excavated.<ref>''Archaeological Encyclopedia of the Holy Land'' (ed. A. Negev & S. Gibson), New York / London 2001, p. 509 [s.v. ''Timnah (c)''] {{ISBN|0-8264-1316-1}}</ref>
===Site's description=== The ancient ruin sits on a high mountain ridge about 2 kilometers west of ''Khirbet Sanasin''. On its site is found the remnant of a square Iron Age fortress which apparently offered security along the route from the [[valley of Elah]] to [[Betar (fortress)|Betar]] and to [[Jerusalem]].<ref name=EncyclopaediaMapa2000>''Encyclopaedia Mapa - A Comprehensive Gazetteer of Israel Today'' (vol. 7), Tel-Aviv 2000, p. 213 {{ISBN|965-7009-92-8}}</ref> The area of the fortress is 30 x 30 meters (98 x 98 feet), where two walls made of [[fieldstone|fieldstones]] and ashlar masonry still remain, whose hollowed spaces were filled-in with smaller stones.<ref name=EncyclopaediaMapa2000 /> [[Amihai Mazar]] suggests that the structure served as either a fortress or an administrative center, and most likely manned by a garrison to secure the roads between the major towns of the [[Shephelah]] and the string of settlements along the edge of the hill region.<ref>[[Amihai Mazar|A. Mazar]], "Abu Tuwein, Khirbet", pub. in: ''The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land'', ed. E. Stern (vol. 1), [[Israel Exploration Society]]: Jerusalem 1993, p. 16 {{ISBN|965-220-209-6}}</ref>
The mound is almost entirely strewn with razed boulders, and ancillary walls, partially standing, are to be seen on the ruin. On its eastern side is a steep declivity, descending down into the valley below, ''Wadi Tibbaneh'' (''Wadi Tibna''), where it joins Etzion Valley (''Wady el Jindy'') to its south at a drop of about {{convert|200|m|ft|}}. The valley seemed to have been used for horticulture in ages past. Sherds dot the landscape, with occasional [[Ceratonia siliqua|carob]] trees, [[Quercus palaestina|oaks]] and [[Rhamnus lycioides|buckthorns]]. Near the site is a modern-day quarry and two ancient cisterns.<ref name=EncyclopaediaMapa2000 /> In close proximity to ''Khirbet et-Tibbaneh'' is the old military patrol road, leading from [[Tzur Hadassah]] to [[Aviezer]].
==History== ''Khirbet et-Tibbaneh'' (''Tibna'') is thought to be the "Tapuna" mentioned in the list of [[Thothmes III]].<ref>[[H.B. Tristram]], ''Bible Places: or, The Topography of the Holy Land: a Succinct Account of All the Places, Rivers, and Mountains of the Land of Israel'', London 1897, p. [https://archive.org/stream/bibleplacesortop00tris#page/82/mode/2up 83]</ref>
Israeli archaeologist [[Michael Avi-Yonah|Avi-Yonah]] also thinks the site to have been the ''Timnah'' (Thamnatha) mentioned in the ''[[First Book of Maccabees]]''<ref>I Macc. 9, 50–52</ref> (and later mentioned by [[Josephus]]),<ref>Josephus, ''[[Antiquities of the Jews|Antiquities]]'' (13.1.3)</ref> one of several places fortified by [[Bacchides (general)|Bacchides]] in ca. 160 BCE after the death of [[Judas Maccabeus]].<ref>M. Avi-Yonah, ''Historical Geography of Palestine'', Jerusalem 1963, p. 37 (note 7); M. Avi-Yonah, ''The Holy Land from the Persian to the Arab Conquests (536 B.C. to A.D. 640) – A Historical Geography'', Grand Rapids 1977, p. 53 {{ISBN|0-8010-0010-6}}. (I. Roll agrees to this view. See: I Roll, "Bacchides' Fortifications and the Arteries of Traffic to Jerusalem in the Hellenistic Period", ''Eretz-Israel'' 25 (1996, pp. 509–514 [Hebrew]); M. Avi-Yonah, ''Gazetteer of Roman Palestine'', Jerusalem 1976, p. 100.</ref> Others suggest that the account in ''Maccabees'' may refer to another Timna (Thamnatha), that called ''[[Khirbet Tibnah|Kh. Tibne]]'' in south-western Samaria, in Mount Ephraim, about 14 kilometers (9 miles) northwest of [[Bethel]].<ref>Zechariah Kallai, ''Northern Boundaries of Judah, from the Settlement of the Tribes Until the Beginning of the Hasmonaean Period'', Jerusalem 1960, p. 96 (Hebrew)</ref><ref>''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'' (ed. David Noel Freedman & Allen C. Meyers), p. 1312</ref>
It is generally accepted that the Mishnaic scholar, [[Simeon of Timnah]], was born and raised in one of the two Timnahs during the waning years of the Second Temple period, based on the vowels assigned to his name, ({{lang-he|שמעון התִּימְנִי|translit=Shimon HaTimni}}). He is noted for saying: "A [[Mamzer|bastard]] is anyone who is born from an [illegal] union for which his progenitors are liable to extirpation at the hands of heaven" <small>([[Mishnah]] ''Yebamot'' 4:13; Babylonian Talmud, ''Yebamot'' 49a)</small>, and which teaching comes to exclude a single parent who gave birth to a child outside of wedlock, and whose child is often wrongly called "[[Legitimacy (family law)|bastard]]" under common law.
==Archaeological finds== As of 2018, the site at ''Kh. Tibbaneh'' has yet to be excavated.<ref>Israeli archaeologist, [[Ze'ev Safrai]], ''Correspondence''</ref> A cursory review of the site has revealed late Iron II sherds.<ref>Amihai Mazar, "The Excavations of Khirbet Abu et-Twain and the System of Iron Age Fortresses in Judah", ''Eretz-Israel'' 15 (1981), p. 246 (Hebrew)</ref>

{{About||the 1978 movie with the same title|King of the Gypsies (film)|the band Gipsy Kings|Gipsy Kings}} {{Romani people}} {{Tone|date=March 2016}} The title '''King of the Gypsies''' has been claimed or given over the centuries to many different people. It is both culturally and geographically specific. It may be inherited, acquired by acclamation or action, or simply claimed. The extent of the power associated with the title varied; it might be limited to a small group in a specific place, or many people over large areas. In some cases the claim was clearly a public relations exercise. As the term [[wikt:gypsy|Gypsy]] is also used in many different ways the ''King of the Gypsies'' may be someone with no connection with the [[Romani people]]. In the early 1970s, it was decided, at the First Annual Romani Meeting that the term Gypsy would no-longer be used to describe themselves. They voted for the term Roma to be used.
It has also been suggested that in places where they were persecuted by local authorities the "King of the Gypsies" is an individual, usually of low standing, who places himself in the risky position of an ad hoc liaison between the Romani and the gadje (non-Romani). The arrest of such a "King" limited the harm to the Romani people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcl.american.edu/hrbrief/09/3roma.cfm |title=Human Rights Brief Human Rights Brief |website=Wcl.american.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
==Scotland== ===John (Johnnie) Faa=== {{main|John Faa}} Johnnie Faa of Dunbar was leader of the 'Egyptians', or Gypsies, in Scotland. Faa was granted a letter under the [[Privy Seal]] from [[James IV of Scotland|King James IV]] in February 1540, which was renewed in 1553. It was addressed to "oure louit Johnne Faw, lord and erle of Litill Egipt" establishing his authority over all Gypsies in Scotland and calling on all [[sheriffs]] in the country to assist him "in executione of justice upoun his company and folkis", who were to "conforme to the lawis of Egipt".
He is resurrected in fiction in S. R. Crockett's ''The Raiders'' and in Philip Pullman's trilogy ''[[His Dark Materials]]''.
===Johnne Wanne=== Son and successor of Johnnie Faa, Johnne Wanne was granted Royal authority over all "Egyptians" in Scotland in May 1540. Records showed that by 1612 the Faa family had extended as far as [[Shetland]]. However, the initial tolerance of Gypsies did not last. In 1623 eight leaders of the Gypsies were hanged on the Burgh Muir, six of whom were of the Faa line. In the 1650s they were amongst those [[Penal transportation|transported]] to [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/roma/gft/index.htm |title=Gypsy Folk Tales Index |website=Sacred-texts.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=== Patrick Faa === Patrick was the first recorded Gypsy King at [[Kirk Yetholm]]. Along with seven other Gypsies he was "sentenced to be transported to the Queen's American for life."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anonymous|first=|date=September 1817|title=NOTICES CONCERNING THE SCOTTISH GYPSIES |url=|journal=Edinburgh Monthly Magazine|volume=1 (September)|pages=616|via=}}</ref>
=== William Faa I === King William I, known as 'Gleed Nickit Wull' because of a twist in the shape of his throat, was born about 1700, and died at Coldingham in 1784, aged around 84. He fathered 24 children by three wives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/will.html|title=Will Faa, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> His death at Colingham is recounted by William Smith, the Baillie at Kelso, who states that "When old Will Faa was upwards of eighty years of age, he called on me in Kelso, in his way to Edinburgh, telling me that he was going to Edinburgh to see the laird... before he died," and also that after successfully completing this visit "he only got the length of Colingham, when he was taken ill and died."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Waverley Anecdotes: Illustrative of the Incidents, Characters, and Scenery, Described in the Novels and Romances, of Sir Walter Scott|last=Scott|first=Walter|publisher=J. Cochrane and J. McCrone|year=1833|isbn=|location=London|pages=217–218}}</ref> Will claimed to be descended from Johnnie Faa, Lord of Little Egypt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/will.html|title=Will Faa, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
===William Faa II=== Will Faa, "King of the Gypsies", died in [[Kirk Yetholm]] on 9 October 1847, aged 96. He was the son of William Faa I. William Faa was an innkeeper (owned "The Queen") and footballer who lived at "The Gypsy Palace" off the Green, and entertained visitors there. The ''Kelso Mail'' carried his obituary entitled "Death of a Gypsy King", which said he was "always accounted a more respectable character than any of his tribe, and could boast of never having been in gaol during his life." His house continued to be a tourist attraction, and there was reportedly an "Old Palace" on the other side of Kirk Yetholm Green. William died without issue in 1847 when the 'Crown' passed to his sister Esther's husband Charles Blythe (1775-1861). Charles was an educated man who did much to live up to his role. On his death in 1861 there was a tussle between his many children for the right to be monarch. The role went to his daughter Esther Faa Blythe who reigned until 1883 when the gypsy culture was in serious decline. Following a gap of several years in 1898 one of her sons Charles Rutherford was persuaded to accept the office and a ceremonial Gypsy Coronation was held in 1898. By this stage the role was largely an attempt to boost tourism. Charles died in 1902 and the title has not been re-established. An Edinburgh housewife is now thought to be the present 'Queen'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discovertheborders.co.uk/places/212.html |title=The Gypsy Palace, Kirk Yetholm, Scotland |website=Discovertheborders.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/ |title=The Scottish Gypsies of Scotland |website=Scottishgypsies.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>‘’Journal Gypsy Lore Soc.’’ 3rd ser.ii 370-1 quoted in ‘’English Genealogy’’ A. R. Wagner</ref> A lancet and case belonging to William Faa II can be found in the collections of the National Museum Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nms.ac.uk/explore-our-collections/collection-search-results/?item_id=25638|title=Case, lancet|website=National Museums Scotland|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
=== Charles Faa Blythe I === Charles Faa Blythe was a brother-in-law to William Faa II, and when he died without issue the title of King of the Gypsies was passed to Charles, husband of his sister, Esther. Charles was born in 1775 and died in 1861. He was crowned King, by the local blacksmith, George Gladstone, on 25 October 1847, aged at least 70 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/charles.html|title=Charles Blyth I, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> He was succeeded by his daughter, Esther Faa Blythe, who was born in the early years of the 1800s and died on 12 July 1883.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/esther3.html|title=Esther Faa Blythe, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
=== Charles Faa Blyth II === Born around 1825, Charles Rutherford (known as Charles Faa Blythe II), was a son to Esther Faa Bythe, the Gypsy Queen. Between the death of Esther Faa Blyth in 1883 and the accession of Charles II in 1898, there was no Gypsy royalty crowned at Kirk Yetholm. His coronation ceremony was really a pageant, with all the locals dressing up for the benefit of the photographers. Many photographs of the occasion still exist.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/charles22.html|title=Charles Faa Blyth II, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
===William (Billy) Marshall=== William (Billy) Marshall (1672-1792) died aged 120, lived in Minnigaff, Kirkcudbrightshire, South West Scotland. Caird of Barullion, King of the Gypsies of the Western Lowlands for 89 years. Served as a soldier at the Battle of the Boyne for William of Orange, Battle of Blenheim. Returned to Scotland where he had an army of 200 followers who ruled the land between Ayr and Dumfries and fought battles at Newton of Ayr, Brig O Doon and Alloway. He was a Protestant, Covenanter, and Leveller. He and his army would champion, the poor, the dispossessed, and steal, disrupt, and organize smuggling activities in cattle, sheep, horses, brandy, whisky, tea, against Jacobites, Landlords, and those that were not locals who were known to him. He was an accomplished craftsman of horn spoons, cups, pots. He is buried in the graveyard at St Cuthbert's Church in [[Kirkcudbright]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Billy Marshall - the Scottish King of the Gypsies|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/education/beyond/factsheets/makhist/makhist10_prog7c.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 June 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041214200506/http://www.bbc.co.uk/education/beyond/factsheets/makhist/makhist10_prog7c.shtml|archivedate=14 December 2004|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> 6 February 2018, AJMcC, The Tinkler Gypsies of Galloway, by Andrew McCormick
==France== ===Florent Léglise=== Often referred as the Ecclesiast, his origins remain unknown but research indicates that he lived around the french territories of the South Gironde. Admired for his famous mystical beard, he became one of the central symbolic representations of authority for french gypsies, as many tales and legends were created and put together from diverse episodes taken from his life (e.g. Catherine's street hidden Church, the Ecclesiast and the last Gitardise, The drummer and the prince, the good, the bad and the Church, etc.). He was nominated by his predecessor, Joni Ali, in 1993 after the battle of the Golden Veal of Bazas, and was crowned after the death of its mentor on the 5th of may of the following year (Joni Ali's Day).
==England== ===Leaders identified in Martin Markall=== The short book ''Martin Markall, [[Beadle]] of the [[Bridewell]]'' was published in London in 1610. The author is given as "S.R.", who is usually identified as [[Samuel Rid]] the author of ''The Art of Jugling or Legerdemaine'', a later book of rogue literature<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Notes and Queries |volume=Eleventh |issue=287 |title=Gypsies in England |publisher=George Bell |date=April 28, 1855 |location=London |page=326}}</ref> promised in Martin Markall. The book is of dubious veracity, and large sections are taken from the works of [[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Gypsy Identities 1500-2000: From Egipcyans and Moon-men to the Ethnic Romany |first=David |last=Mayall |publisher=Routledge |date=Oct 9, 2003 |page=69}}</ref> although [[Frank Aydelotte]], who dates the book to 1608, calls it mostly original.<ref>{{cite book |title=Elizabethan Rogues and Vagabonds |first=Frank |last=Aydelotte |page=unnumbered |publisher=Routledge |edition=5th |year=2013}}</ref> It includes what purports to be a list of the leaders of "the regiment of rogues", which echoed the genealogies of prominent families. It will be seen that in reality few had anything to do with Gypsies, but they are indicative of the context in which some of the Kings of the Gypsies were identified.
====John Mendall==== aka [[Jack Cade]], aka John Mortimer, who led a rebellion of men from Kent who camped at Blackheath outside London in 1450. After his rebellion a reward was offered for him, and he was captured and killed in Kent.
====Bluebeard and Hugh Roberts==== Both soldiers who had served in France. Bluebeard was captured and executed shortly after being made "their captain". Roberts then gathered about 100 "rakehells and vagabonds" in Kent who were joined by 400 "masterless men". Together they joined Jack Cade and entered [[Southwark]]. After the end of Cade's rebellion Roberts took to the woods with a small group living by theft, according to set rules of their own. After a year living like this these "Roberdsmen" dispersed throughout England, vowing to meet every three years, and joining other "commotions and rebellions". Roberts also went "roving" and "kept his court" until he was killed in 1461.
====Jenkin Cowdiddle==== Was chosen by the remaining "Roberdsmen" at "their wonted place of meeting" "by general assent". He was "a wandering rogue", "much given to swearing, drunkenness and lechery . . . stout of stomach, audacious and fierce". He claimed ''[[droit du seigneur]]'', and ordained that all beggars spent their weekly earnings in full every Saturday night. Rid says that he fought with "300 tattered knaves" in the rebellion in the South West of England against [[Edward IV]] and was killed at the [[Battle of Tewkesbury]] (1471). Unlike Roberts, who may have been a real character, this Cowdiddle seems to have been a complete fiction.
====Spising==== Not deterred, the remaining "Roberdsmen" "hie them to their rendezvous . . . and there, with the full consent of the whole company, they chose one Spising to be his successor". Spising is given no first name. He is credited with ordering that all begging wanderers be "stalled as a rogue" by "the Chief Commander then being", paying a fee in beer, though this was excused if his father and grandfather had been rogues. Spising joined the larger rebellion by Thomas Neville, the [[Bastard of Fauconberg]]. He led a band attacking [[Aldgate]], and was nearly successful, until parts of his group were trapped by the fall of the [[portcullis]]. Spising is reputed to have ruled 11 years before being hanged for a murder in [[Wombourn]], [[Staffordshire]], having escaped the same fate earlier by seeking [[sanctuary]] in [[Westminster Abbey]]. There is a historical record of a Spising as leader of an [[Essex]] contingent of Neville's uprising, but he was executed after it, and his head exhibited on Aldgate.
====Puff Dick==== Was the next elected, an expert at cheating with [[loaded dice]], and excelled in "all manner of vice". He repeated Cowdiddle's requirement for thieves and beggars to spend their ill-gotten gains and not save them. Rid says he ruled for 8 years before dying of "the [[French pox|[French] pox]] and Neapolitan scurf". Like Cowdiddle, Dick seems to have been wholly fictional.
====Laurence Crossbiter (aka Long Laurence)==== Laurence Crossbiter was the next elected leader, a serving man aged 50–60. His art was "crossbiting"; theft from the customers of whores. He is also reported to have died "his bowels . . . eaten out with the pox while he was yet alive". Rid described him as cowardly and slavish for failing to come to the aid of the rebel [[Perkin Warbeck]].
====Richard Skelton==== Was one of Warbeck's counsellors, "a noted knave". He was next "led to the wonted place of meeting, and there solemnly stalled a rogue and made their general". He is described as formerly having been a [[tailor]] in [[Taunton]], [[Somerset]] "of proud and haughty disposition", and have "lived in this new government" until 1501. A Skelton was recorded by [[Sir Francis Bacon]] as a counsellor to Warbeck, but he says nothing of his activities after the rebellion.
====Cock Lorel==== Was elected his successor "by the General Council". Cock Lorel was "the most notorious knave that ever lived" who ruled until 1533. He professed the trade of a tinker to cover his thefts. Rid says that his knaveries are recorded in an old manuscript kept as "Maunders’ Hall", giving the rogue community a similar structure of that of the trade [[guilds]]. Cock Lorel was the great mythical leader of Tudor rogues. His name means just that, "cock" being leader, and "lorel" or losel" meaning rascal. He first appears about 1500 in "Cock Lorel's Boat", and is mentioned in [[Robert Copland]]'s ''The Highway to the Spitalhouse'' (1535). He is credited with approving John Awdesley's ''The Fraternity of Vagabonds'', (1561), in which he is given as the creator of the Twenty Five Orders of Knaves, reproduced in [[Thomas Harman]]'s ''Warning for Common Cursitors'' and many other works of rogue literature. There is no record of any real individual on whom he was based. Cock Lorel is credited with having held a meeting with the leader of the Egyptians, Giles Hather, at their base at [[Peak Cavern|The Devils Arse Apeak]] in [[Derbyshire]]. Rid claims that at this meeting they devised a new and secret language [[Thieves' Cant]], "to the end that their cozenings, knaveries, and villainies might not so easily be perceived and known".<ref>Rid, Samuel (1610). ''Martin Markall, the Beadle of Bridewell''. as quoted in {{cite book |title=Becoming Criminal: Transversal Performance and Cultural Dissidence in Early Modern England (Google eBook) |first=Bryan |last=Reynolds |page=unnumbered |publisher=JHU Press |date=Apr 1, 2003}}</ref>
====Giles Hather==== Became head of the regiment or fellowship of Egyptians in the north about 1528. These, Rid says, travelled in groups of more than a hundred men and women, with horses, their faces blacked, and practised [[legerdemain]] and [[fortune telling]] by [[palmistry]], delighting the common people with their clothes.
====Kit Callot==== "the Queen of the Egypties" accompanied Giles Hather, according to Rid. These names were traditional; Hather is mentioned by Thomas Awdesley (1561). "Kit" and "Callot" as names can be traced back to [[Piers Plowman]]. Although Tudor government, both local and national, took a close interest in the Egyptians there is no record of the names in their records.
===Other leaders=== ====Boswells==== The Boswells were for centuries one of England's largest and most important Gypsy families. The Boswell clan were a large extended family of [[Romani people|Travellers]], and in old [[Nottinghamshire dialect]] the word ''bos'll'' was used as a term for Travellers and Romani in general.
=====Haniel Boswell===== Was the son of Francis Boswell.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.garenewing.co.uk/family/hodgkins.html |title=The Romani Line - Boswell, Sherriff & Hodgkins or Hodgkinson |website=Garenewing.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Jacob Rewbrey===== "Alias king of the Gypsies", from the St Margaret's [[Westminster]], was tried at the [[Old Bailey]] on 28 August 1700 for theft with violence and highway robbery. It was alleged he had robbed "one Rebecca Sellers, near the High way, . . . taking from her 3 Gold-rings, and 9 s. in Money" in January of that year. The Jury found him Guilty of theft, but not Robbery, as "It appeared that he juggled [tricked] her out of it." He was sentenced to [[Penal transportation]].<ref>{{Old Bailey|defendant=Jacob Rewbrey|trialdate=28 August 1700|id=t17000828-63|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
=====James Boswell===== Is buried in [[Rossington]], near [[Doncaster]] in [[Yorkshire]]. Langdale's "Topographical Dictionary of Yorkshire" (1822), says: "In the church yard, was a stone, the two ends of which are now remaining, where was interred the body of James Bosvill the King of the Gypsies, who died January 30, 1708. For a number of years, it was a custom of Gypsies from the south, to visit his tomb annually, and there perform some of their accustomed rites; one of which was to pour a flagon of ale upon the grave." This is similar to the ritual of "stalling the rogue" mentioned by [[Thomas Harman]] and in ''The Beggars Bush'' and by [[Bampfylde Moore Carew]].
A tradition was reported of annual visits to the grave of Charles Boswell near Doncaster for more than 100 years into the 1820s, including a rite of pouring a flagon of hot ale into the tomb. This may be same person.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.donny.co.uk/Doncaster/news/index.php3?ID=376 |title=Doncaster News and Features: Bizarre Doncaster: Ghosts and Hauntings, on Donny Online |website=Donny.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>[[Brian Vesey-Fitzgerald]] Gypsies of Britain, The Country Book Club, 1951, quoting Edward Miller History and Antiquities of Doncaster</ref><ref>John Wainwright, History and Antiquities of Doncaster and Consborough, Sheffield, Basil Blackwell., 1829</ref> the grave is situated by the main door leading to the church, shaded by a dark oak tree. It is now covered in moss, but is still readable. The words "King Of The Gypsies" will lie there for ever more, whereas the mystery of the black cat is still unsolved. – information on the grave by A. Needham – P. Needham, of St. Michaels church.''
=====Henry Boswell===== "King of the Gypsies" died in 1760 at the age of 90 and was buried at [[Ickleford]] near [[Hitchin]], [[Hertfordshire]] at the church of St. Catherine, as were his wife and granddaughter. Royal National and Commercial Directory and Topography of Herts, Pigot & Co., London, 1839<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pjoiner.demon.co.uk/genuki/HRT/Ickleford/index.html|title=GENUKI - Ickleford|date=11 October 2006|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061011062618/http://www.pjoiner.demon.co.uk/genuki/HRT/Ickleford/index.html|archivedate=11 October 2006|df=}}</ref>
=====Edmund Mashiter===== aka "Old Honey", died in [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]] in 1811 aged 90. He was reported to have been "justly entitled the King of Beggars", having been on the road for 70 years. He was reported to have been the son of a schoolmaster, and well educated, but to have taken to the road by choice, and maintained a wandering life until he became bedridden. <ref>''The Gentleman's Magazine'', 1 March 1811.</ref>
=====Henry Boswell===== The "King of the Gypsies" died in 1824 [[Stamford, Lincolnshire]].<ref>''Rutland & Stamford Mercury'' 15 October 1824 p3 column 1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolnshire.gov.uk/section.asp?docId=45657 |title=Gypsies | Lincolnshire County Council |website=Lincolnshire.gov.uk |date=2012-06-07 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Louis Boswell===== Louis Boswell was buried at [[St. Laurence and All Saints Church, Eastwood|Eastwood church]], [[Southend-on-Sea]] in 1835. In the Burial Register he is described as a "Traveller aged 42" – "This man known as the King of the Gypsies was interred in the presence of a vast concourse of spectators".<ref>{{cite web|title=King of Gypsies Edward Boswell|url=http://gypsyjib.wetpaint.com/page/KING+OF+GYPSIES+EDWARD+BOSWELL |publisher=Rromani djib|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref>
====Non Boswells==== =====Unknown, Calne===== In the churchyard of [[St Mary's Church, Calne|St Mary's]] parish church, [[Calne]], [[Wiltshire]], a tomb commemorating an unknown King of the Gypsies is set in the wall.<ref>{{cite web|title=Calne|url=http://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/leisure/outabout/tourism/townsandvillages/wtcalne/|website=Wiltshire Gazette and Herald|accessdate=18 March 2016}}</ref>
=====Harry Burton===== Described as "King of the Gypsies", died in the [[Workhouse]] in [[Wincanton]], [[Somerset]] aged 94 in 1847.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wincanton-online.com/wincanton.htm|title=Wincanton|date=5 April 2005|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050405030917/http://www.wincanton-online.com/wincanton.htm|archivedate=5 April 2005|df=}}</ref>
=====Matty Cooper===== Taught the [[Romani language]] in the 1870s to [[Charles Godfrey Leland]] (1824–1903), the American folklorist and founder of the Gypsy Lore Society. Leland claimed Cooper was the King of the Gypsies in England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themystica.com/mystica/articles/l/Leland_charles_godfrey.html |title=Leland, Charles Godfrey |website=Themystica.com |date=1903-03-20 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Xavier Petulengro/ Smith ===== Was described as the King of the Gypsies, in an account of a Romani wedding at [[Baildon]] in [[Yorkshire]] in 1937 between his son Leon Petulengro/ Smith and Illeana Smith both of Colchester Essex. According to the caption of a photograph [[Xavier Petulengro]] cut the hands of the couple to mingle their blood during the ceremony. After their wedding the couple went north to Blackpool. During the war Leon was in the RAF and Ileana (Eileen) was a staff car driver for ICI. The marriage was dissolved in 1947 in Nottingham. Baildon was a famous fair and meeting place for Gypsies. Petulengro/ Smith was well known as a broadcaster on Gypsy subjects. His son Leon Petulengro/ Smith wrote for the "Woman's Own" magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scienceandsociety.co.uk/results.asp?image=10249897&wwwflag=3&imagepos=1 |title=Stock photo and image search by Science & Society Picture Library |website=Scienceandsociety.co.uk |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Gilderoy Scamp===== Born in [[Orpington]], [[Kent]] early 20th century. Lived in [[Folkestone]], Kent.<ref>''Gilderoy Scamp – King of the Gypsies'', Linda Hayward, ''Rromani Routes'' Volume 4 No 7 June 2000</ref>
=====Louis Welch===== Louis Welch of [[Darlington]] was described by British media as the "King of the Gypsies", a title given to the best bare-knuckled boxer in the [[Romanichal]] - mainly from the UK, and France community, following an alleged attack by six knife-wielding men, possibly from a rival band of travellers, in [[Cumbria]]. He refused to give evidence against his attackers, saying it was "against the travellers' code of honour", and a retrial was ordered after the jury failed to reach a verdict.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/8552394.stm|title=Retrial over 'King of Gypsies' boxer attack in Cumbria|publisher=BBC|date=2010-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/673657-king-of-the-gypsies-injured-in-knife-attack |title='King of the Gypsies' injured in knife attack | Metro News |website=Metro.co.uk |date=2009-05-27 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/5025032._Ignore_whims_of_King_of_the_Gipsies_/|title=Ignore whims of King of the Gipsies|publisher=The Northern Echo|date=2010-02-24}}</ref>
==Wales== ===Abram Wood=== Abram Wood was the head of a family of Welsh gypsies in the 1700s. They were musicians, and spoke an old Romani dialect.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts About Wales & the Welsh: Welsh gypsies were the last to speak Romani in Europe|url=http://britannia.com/celtic/wales/facts/facts7.html|publisher=Wales on Britannia|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref>
==Norway== ===Karoli family=== In the 1980s, Polykarp Karoli began styling himself "King of all Gypsies in Norway".<ref>''Aftenposten'' 1989.12.27: ''Sigøynerkongen tatt i København''</ref>
In 1990, while most of the family was serving prison time, Polykarp's grandson Martin Erik Karoli proclaimed himself "King of One Million Gypsies", claiming to be slated for a hundreds of years old crowning ceremony in Central Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.retriever-info.com/services/webdocument.html?documentId=00230420080411105035364&serviceId=2 |title=Retriever |website=Web.retriever-info.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> After Polykarp's death in 2001, his two sons publicly rivalled for the title "King of All Gypsies in The World", estimating 47.8 million subjects throughout the world and citing various ancient ceremonies and royal registries.<ref>''VG'' 2001.08.11: ''Jeg er den nye kongen!''</ref>
==Italy== ===Scaramuccia=== This "King of the Gypsies" is suggested as a possible model for "A Grotesque Head" of the sketches of human physiognomy by [[Leonardo da Vinci]], dated to (c.1503-07). [[Giorgio Vasari]] reported that Leonardo had done a drawing of "the Gypsy Captain Scaramuccia" which Vasari possessed, but it is not known what happened to it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chch.ox.ac.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=21&Itemid=234 |title=Christ Church, Oxford University |website=Chch.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
==Romania== ===Iulian Rădulescu=== In 1993, Iulian Rădulescu proclaimed himself "Emperor of the Roma Everywhere".<ref>[[:ro:Iulian Rădulescu]]</ref>
===Florin Cioabă=== [[Florin Cioabă]] acquired the title "King of the Roma Everywhere" in 1997 from his father Ioan Cioabă who had claimed the title in 1992. Reports in 2003 that Cioabă, a [[Pentecostal]] Minister, had married off his own daughter at the age of 12 (or 14) caused uproar in the western media. The [[UN]] Economic and Social Council visited him in 1999 when preparing a report on Racism and Intolerance and described him as devoting himself to economic activity to support community projects, and exerting "[[moral authority]]" and having "some influence" as a councillor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cidcm.umd.edu/inscr/mar/chronology.asp?groupId=36003|title=MAR - Data - Chronology for Roma in Romania|date=28 August 2004|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040828191802/http://www.cidcm.umd.edu/inscr/mar/chronology.asp?groupId=36003|archivedate=28 August 2004|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.developmentinaction.org/newspages/index/64.php|title=Development in Action - The thorny issues surrounding the practice of child marriage – cultural tradition or economic necessity?|date=26 December 2004|website=Developmentinaction.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041226114518/http://www.developmentinaction.org/newspages/index/64.php|archivedate=26 December 2004|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.soros.org/initiatives/health/focus/roma/articles_publications/articles/underground_20060727/sibiu_20060711.pdf |title=Open Society Foundations |publisher=Soros.org |date=2016-11-22 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> He died on August 18, 2013 after suffering a heart attack while on holiday in Antalya, Turkey.<ref>{{cite news|last=Childs|first=David|title=Obituary: Florin Cioaba: Activist and 'King of the Rroma'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/florin-cioaba-activist-and-king-of-the-Rroma-8780991.html|work=The Independent|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=27 September 2013|location=London|date=22 August 2013}}</ref> He was succeeded as King by his son Dorin Cioabă.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/an-audience-with-the-king-of-the-gypsies|title=An Audience With the 'King of the Gypsies'|publisher=Vice.com|author1=Sara Winston|author2=Martin Krupik|date=5 July 2014|accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref>
===John Kyle=== In 2003, according to a decree issued by Emperor Iulian, John Kyle was proclaimed "International King of the Roma".<ref>{{cite news |title=La Mânăstirea Curtea de Argeş s-au sfinţit doar podoabele specifice rromilor |url=http://www.curierulnational.ro/?page=articol&editie=301&art=20984 |work=Curierul Naţional |date=September 3, 2003|language=ro}}</ref>
==Hungary== ===Tamás Bolgár=== He was named as voivode of the "Pharaoh's People" in 1496. He seems to have led a group of metalworkers, as he was supplying the Bishop of [[Pécs]] with cannonballs. He was almost certainly the same person granted privileges by the King of [[Poland]] and [[Lithuania]] in 1501, who also recognised the privileges of '''Wasili''' as leader of the "Cyhany"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amarodrom.hu/archivum/99/10/0.html|title=Záróra|date=31 December 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231132151/http://www.amarodrom.hu/archivum/99/10/0.html|archivedate=31 December 2007|df=}}</ref> <!-- of the 120 Rroma who arrived at Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary, (in German it called: Kronstadt, now Braşov, Romania) in 1516. -->
==Poland== ===Matiasz Korolewicz=== Was conferred the title "King of the Gypsies" by the Polish Royal Chancery in 1652, after the death of '''Janczy''' who had previously served as the head of the Roma. Later Kings of the Gypsies seem to have been appointed from the aristocracy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romanothan.ro/romana/istorie/resurse_patrin.htm |title=Visitor anti-robot validation |website=Romanothan.ro |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Janusz Kwiek=== Was crowned as Janos I, King of the Gypsies, before thousands of people in 1937. He announced his intention to petition [[Benito Mussolini]] for land for a Romani settlement in [[East Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romahistory.com/en/2-5-11.htm|title=layout|date=27 September 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195107/http://www.romahistory.com/en/2-5-11.htm|archivedate=27 September 2007|df=}}</ref>
==Bulgaria== ===Shibilis=== The Gypsy King is associated with mythical powers of being able to part water with his sword, a spade, and his head, after it had been cut off, according to tales collected in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://romaculture.cult.bg/DOCLAD.htm |title=ROMA IN BULGARIA AND THEIR FOLKLORE |last=Kolev |first=Deyan |author2=Teodora Krumova |date=January 14, 2002 |publisher=Protecting and Popularizing Roma Culture in Central Bulgaria |accessdate=2009-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050529140955/http://romaculture.cult.bg/DOCLAD.htm |archivedate=May 29, 2005 }}</ref>
==United States of America== ===M. H. Frank=== Who had lived in [[Meridian, Mississippi]], was chosen as King after Emil Mitchell's death in 1942.<ref>''Meridian Dispatch'' 7th February1915</ref><ref>''Meridian Star'' 5 August 1960</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciway3.net/clark/freemoors/emilmitchell.html |title=Emil Mitchel Family |website=Sciway3.net |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://foclark.tripod.com/gypsy/rosehill.html |title=Free Moors and "Turks" in South Carolina |website=Foclark.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://foclark.tripod.com/gypsy/emilmitchell.html |title=Emil Mitchel Family |website=Foclark.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Elijah George=== Described as king of the Gypsies at the time of the massive search for [[Elsie Paroubek]]. Mr. George was contacted in Argyle, Wisconsin, and taken to Joliet, Illinois for questioning; but he knew nothing and was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/386756031.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+9%2C+1911&author=&pub=Chicago+Daily+Tribune+%281872-1922%29&edition=&startpage=1&desc=CANAL+YIELDS+UP+BODY+OF+MISSING+ELSIE+PAROUBEK |title=Archives: Chicago Tribune - CANAL YIELDS UP BODY OF MISSING ELSIE PAROUBEK |website=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com |date=1911-05-09 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Unidentified Romany=== In 1953, [[Anaïs Nin]] underwent surgery for ovarian cancer in a Los Angeles hospital. In her diary, she mentions that "the King of the Gypsies was having surgery at the same time" and that approximately six hundred members of his tribe were camped in or near the hospital in accordance with their law: "no amount of hospital discipline would drive them away". She spoke with several members of the band, and identified them as Romani people.<ref>Anaïs Nin, ''Diary Of Anaïs Nin Volume 5 1947-1955: Vol. 5 (1947-1955)'', p. 106-107.</ref>
==Venezuela== ===Angelo Vallerugo III=== Since 1998, Angelo Vallerugo III has been accepted by the Venezuelan gypsy community as their one and only king.<ref>Caceres, Jorge (1987). "Gypsys In Venezuela", 3rd ed., Santillana</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name =Laurence Gardner | image = Laurence Gardner.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1943|05|17|df=yes}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|08|12|1943|05|17|df=yes}} | birth_place =UK, London | occupation =author | nationality =British }} '''Laurence Gardner''' (17 May 1943 – 12 August 2010) was a British author and lecturer. He wrote on subjects such as the [[Jesus bloodline]], anti-gravity and the cloning of Adam and Eve.
==Career== Laurence Gardner's first book ''Bloodline of the Holy Grail'' was published during 1996.<ref>Laurence Gardner, ''Bloodline of The Holy Grail: The Hidden Lineage of Jesus Revealed'' (Shaftesbury: Element, 1996. {{ISBN|1-85230-870-2}})</ref> The book was serialized in the [[Daily Mail]] and was a best seller.<ref name="obituary" /> He used his books to propose several theories, including a belief that Jesus and [[Mary Magdalene]] had married and had children, whose descendants included [[King Arthur]] and the [[House of Stuart]].<ref name="obituary" /> In ''Lost Secrets of the Sacred Ark'' he claimed that the [[Ark of the Covenant]] was a machine for manufacturing "monatomic gold" – a supposed elixir which could be used to extend life.<ref>Gardner, Lawrence (2004). ''Lost Secrets of the Sacred Ark: Amazing Revelations of the Incredible Power of Gold''. {{ISBN|0-00-714295-1}}.</ref> His books also included theories about [[Freemasons|Freemasonry]], the [[Knights Templar]], [[The Holy Grail]] and proposed connections between [[Atenism]] and [[Judaism]].
Gardner [[False titles of nobility|referred to himself]] as "Chevalier Labhran de Saint Germain", and "Presidential Attache to the European Council of Princes" (the existence of which cannot be verified<ref name=Picknett>{{cite book|last=Picknett|first=Lynn|title=The Sion Revelation : The Truth about the Guardians of Christ's Sacred Bloodline.|year=2006|publisher=Touchstone books|location=New York, N.Y.|isbn=9780743263030|pages=281–84|author2=Prince, Clive }}</ref>) also "Prior of the Celtic Churches Sacred Kindred of Saint Columbia".<ref>[http://www.entropic-art.com/book.html Entropic Fine Art Inc – Book<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505103651/http://www.entropic-art.com/book.html |date=5 May 2007 }}</ref> He also claimed to be [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] Historiographer Royal of the [[House of Stuart|Royal House of Stewart]]. He was an endorser of [[Michael Lafosse]], in particular his claims to be descended from the [[House of Stuart]], which Gardner claimed was descended from [[Jesus Christ]].<ref name="king">[https://www.theguardian.com/g2/story/0,,308415,00.html The man who would be king]—from The Guardian, 24 March 1999</ref><ref>[http://www.alpheus.org/html/reviews/esoteric_history/rev_gardner.htm Two reviews] of Gardner's book ''Bloodline of the Holy Grail''</ref>
Historians and scholars regard him as a [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorist]],<ref>Damian Thompson, ''[[Counterknowledge]]'' (2008), Clive Cheeseman, Jonathan Williams, ''Rebels, Pretenders & Impostors'' (2000), Kevin McClure, ''Gullible's Travels'', reviewing Gardner's book ''The Shadow of Solomon'' for ''[[Fortean Times]]'' No 203 (November 2005); and ''Time for Suspension of Belief'', reviewing Gardner's book ''The Magdalene Legacy'' for ''Fortean Times'' No 198 (July 2005), stating that Gardner doesn't respond to inquiries relating to the contents of his books.</ref> and treat his work as [[pseudohistory]].<ref name="king"/> Michel Lafosse's claims have been dismissed.<ref>http://homepage.eircom.net/~seanjmurphy/chiefs/lafosse.htm, Report on the Pedigree of Michel Lafosse, Styled Prince Michael of Albany</ref>
Laurence Gardner was also known in the United States for his radio telephone-ins.<ref name="obituary" />
He died on 12 August 2010 after a prolonged illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://graal.co.uk/index.html |title=Chronicles of the Holy Grail – Official announcement |publisher=gral.co.uk – The official website of Laurence Gardner |accessdate=16 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805011101/http://graal.co.uk/index.html |archivedate= 5 August 2010 |df= }}</ref>
His book, ''The Origin Of God'', was published in 2010 as a [[print on demand]] book from the Dash House Publishing Company,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dashhousepublishing.co.uk/|title=Dash House Publishing Company|accessdate=13 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230151524/http://www.dashhousepublishing.co.uk/|archivedate=30 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> established by his widow. It is described as "a biographical exploration of the deiform character variously known as Yahweh, Allah, or simply The Lord. It seeks to uncover and evaluate his original identity...".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dashhousepublishing.co.uk/book_the_origin_of_god.php|publisher=Dash House Publishing|title=Book – The Origin of God|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107094444/http://www.dashhousepublishing.co.uk/book_the_origin_of_god.php|archivedate=7 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His final book ''Revelation of the Devil'', a companion to ''The Origin of God'', was published by Dash in 2012.
==Personal life== Gardner was born in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], London. He was married to Angela and they had one child together and two children from a previous marriage.<ref name="obituary">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/laurence-gardner-alternative-historian-whose-work-helped-inspire-dan-brown-2056096.html|title=Laurence Gardner: Alternative historian whose work helped inspire Dan Brown|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=19 August 2010|accessdate=19 August 2010}}</ref> He was a [[stockbroker]] before becoming an author. Gardner was also an artistic painter, working alone and with Canadian artist Peter Robson.<ref name="obituary" />

=== K === *'''[[Pyotr Kafarov]]''', prominent [[sinologist]], discovered many invaluable manuscripts, including ''[[The Secret History of the Mongols]]'' *'''[[Nikolai Karamzin]]''', [[sentimentalist]] writer and historian, author of the 12-volume ''History of the Russian State'', the principal early 19th-century account of national history *'''[[Vasily Klyuchevsky]]''', dominated Russian historiography at the turn of the 20th century, shifted focus from politics and society to geography and economy *'''[[Alexander Kazhdan]]''', [[Byzantinist]], editor of the ''[[Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium]]'' *'''[[Nikodim Kondakov]]''', prominent researcher of [[Byzantine art]] *'''[[Andrey Korotayev]]''', historian and anthropologist, a founder of [[cliodynamics]], a prominent developer of [[social cycle theory]] *'''[[Nikolay Kostomarov]]''', historian, folklorist and romantic writer, researched the differences between [[Great Russia]] and [[Little Russia]] and the history of [[Ukraine]][[File:Vasily Klyuchevsky 2.jpg|thumb|85px|'''[[Vasily Klyuchevsky|Klyuchevsky]]''']] *'''[[Pyotr Kozlov]]''', explorer of [[Central Asia]], discoverer of the ancient [[Tangut people|Tangut]] city of [[Khara-Khoto]] and [[Xiongnu]] royal burials at [[Noin-Ula]] *'''[[Yelena Yefimovna Kuzmina]]''', prominent researcher of prehistory of Indo-Aryan peoples
===L=== *'''[[Platon Levshin]]''', president of the [[Most Holy Synod]] during the [[Age of Enlightenment]], author of the first systematic course of the history of [[Russian Orthodox Church]] *'''[[Nikolay Likhachyov]]''', first and foremost Russian [[sigillographer]], prominent also in a number of other auxiliary historical disciplines *'''[[Aleksey Lobanov-Rostovsky]]''', statesman, published the major ''Russian [[Genealogical]] Book'' *'''[[Mikhail Lomonosov]]''', polymath scientist and artist, the first opponent of the [[Normanist theory]], published an early account of Russian history
===M=== *'''[[Madhavan K. Palat]]''', since 1989 Professor of Russian and European History, Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi, India. Visiting Professor of Imperial Russian History at the University of Chicago (2006). * '''[[Boris Marshak]]''', excavated the [[Sogdian people|Sogdian]] ruins at [[Panjakent]] * '''[[Friedrich Martens]]''', legal historian, drafted the [[Martens Clause]] of the [[Hague Peace Conference]][[File:Gerhard Friedrich Müller.jpg|thumb|90px|'''[[Gerhardt Friedrich Müller|Müller]]''']] * '''[[Vladimir Minorsky]]''', prominent historian of [[Persia]] * '''[[Yagutil Mishiev]]''', writer, author of books about the history of [[Derbent]], [[Dagestan]], [[Russia]]. * '''[[Anatoly Moskvin]]''', [[Linguistics|linguist]] and [[history|historian]], arrested in 2011 after the bodies of 26 mummified young women were discovered in his home. * '''[[Gerhardt Friedrich Müller]]''', co-founder of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], explorer and the first academic historian of [[Siberia]], a founder of [[ethnography]], author of the first academic account of [[Russian history]], put forth the [[Normanist theory]] * '''[[Aleksei Musin-Pushkin]]''', prominent collector of ancient Russian manuscripts, discovered ''[[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]''
===O=== *'''[[Dimitri Obolensky]]''', [[Byzantine commonwealth]] researcher *'''[[Alexey Okladnikov]]''', prominent historian and archaeologist of [[Siberia]] and [[Mongolia]][[File:Alexei Ivanovich Musin-Pushkin.jpg|thumb|100px|'''[[Musin-Pushkin]]''']] *'''[[Sergey Oldenburg]]''', a founder of Russian [[Indology]] and the [[Academic Institute of Oriental Studies]] *'''[[George Ostrogorsky]]''', preeminent 20th century [[Byzantinist]]
===P=== *'''[[Avraamy Palitsyn]]''', 17th-century historian of the [[Time of Troubles]] *'''[[Anna Pankratova]]''' (1897–1957), leading Soviet historian, educator and writer *'''[[Evgeny Pashukanis]]''', legal historian, wrote ''The General Theory of Law and [[Marxism]]'' *'''[[Boris Piotrovsky]]''', prominent researcher of [[Urartu]], [[Scythia]], and [[Nubia]], long-term director of the [[Hermitage Museum]] *'''[[Mikhail Piotrovsky]]''', orientalist, current director of the [[Hermitage Museum]] *'''[[Mikhail Pogodin]]''', leading mid-19th-century Russian historian, proponent of the [[Normanist theory]] *'''[[Boris Petrovich Polevoy|Boris Polevoy]]''', major historian of the [[Russian Far East]] *'''[[Mikhail Pokrovsky]]''', [[Marxist]] historian prominent in 1920s[[File:Michail Pogodin.jpg|thumb|95px|'''[[Pogodin]]''']] *'''[[Natalia Polosmak]]''', archaeologist of [[Pazyryk burials]], discoverer of [[Pazyryk Ice Maiden|Ice Maiden]] [[mummy]] *'''[[Alexander Polovtsov]]''', statesman, historian and [[Maecenas]], founder of the Russian Historian Society *'''[[Tatyana Proskuryakova]]''', [[Mayanist]] scholar and archaeologist, deciphered the ancient [[Maya script]]
===R=== *'''[[Semyon Remezov]]''', cartographer and the first historian of [[Siberia]], author of the ''[[Remezov Chronicle]]'' *'''[[Mikhail Rostovtsev]]''', archeologist and economist, the first to thoroughly examine the social and economic systems of the [[Ancient World]], excavated [[Dura-Europos]] *'''[[Nicholas Roerich]]''', painter, archeologist, and public figure, explorer of [[Central Asia]], initiator of the international [[Roerich’s Pact]] on protection of historical monuments *'''[[Sergei Rudenko]]''', discoverer of [[Scythian]] [[Pazyryk burials]] *'''[[Boris Rybakov]]''', historian and chief Soviet archaeologist for 40 years, primary opponent of the [[Normanist theory]][[File:Charsolomon TProskouriakoff.jpg|thumb|90px|'''[[Tatyana Proskuryakova|Proskuryakova]]''']]
===S=== *'''[[Dmitry Samokvasov]]''', discoverer of [[Black Grave]] in [[Chernigov]] *'''[[Viktor Sarianidi]]''', discoverer of the [[Bactria-Margiana Archaeological Complex]] and the ''[[Bactrian Gold]]'' in [[Central Asia]] *'''[[Mikhail Shcherbatov]]''', a man of [[Russian Enlightenment]], conservative historian *'''[[Sergey Solovyov]]''', principal Russian 19th-century historian, author of the 29-volume ''History of Russia'' *'''[[Vasily Vasilievich Struve|Vasily Struve]]''', orientalist and historian of the [[Ancient World]], put forth the [[Marxist]] theory of five socio-economic formations that dominated the Soviet education

revision.text:
[[File:Euromaidan in Kyiv early afternoon 2013-09-12 (088).JPG|thumb|upright|Destroyed monument of Lenin near Bessarabsky Market in Kiev, pulled down by demonstrators on December 8, 2013]] [[File:Destructed Lenin monument Kharkiv 2.JPG|thumb|upright|Destroyed monument of Lenin in Freedom Square, Kharkiv, pulled down by demonstrators on September 29, 2014]] In [[Ukraine]] '''monuments to Lenin and other [[Soviet-era]] monuments''' are to be removed within a six months period that started on 15 May 2015.[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2015/05/15/7068057/ Poroshenko signed the laws about decomunization]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. 15 May 2015
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/265988.html Poroshenko signs laws on denouncing Communist, Nazi regimes], [[Interfax-Ukraine]]. 15 May 20
[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols], [[BBC News]] (14 April 2015) Since [[Ukrainian independence]] (in 1991) communist monuments were already being removed[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-287098.html Ukraine to remove 10 Soviet-era monuments], [[UNIAN]] (28-11-2008) and till 2014 new monuments were also erected.[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-312409.html Two Lenin monuments opened in Luhansk Oblast], [[UNIAN]] (April 22, 2008) In the aftermath of the 2013-2014 [[Euromaidan]] protests many of them were recently toppled. On 15 May 2015 [[President of Ukraine]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the bill into law that started a six months period for the removal of the communist monuments. ==Outlawing of communist monuments== {{main|Fall of the monument to Lenin in Kiev|Decommunization in Ukraine}} ===Early attempts=== On 6 October 2009, addressing participants of the Second Ecumenical Week held in [[Ukrainian Catholic University]], (then) [[First Lady of Ukraine|First Lady]] [[Kateryna Yushchenko]] called on all [[Ukrainians]] to pull down monuments to the Communist past. According to her, the [[Ukrainian SSR|Communist regime]] had been consistently active in destroying the [[Ukrainian church]]. "Having destroyed age-long belief in Christ, the Communists proposed their own idols instead; the culture and [[Religion in Ukraine|faith of Ukrainians]] was deformed and are in need of renovation", according to Kateryna Yushchenko.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/western-information-agency-first-lady-calls-to-pul-50208.html], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 7, 2009) ===Pulling down of monuments=== The removal or destruction of Lenin monuments and statues gained particular momentum during the [[EuroMaidan]] movement in the beginning of 2014. Under the motto "Ленінопад" (Leninopad, translated into English as "Leninfall"), activists pulled down a dozen monuments in the Kiev region, Zhytomyr, Khmelnitsky, and elsewhere, or damaged them.http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/leninopad-trivaye-vozhdya-skinuli-v-kanevi-mikolayevi-hersoni-336067.html In other cities and towns, monuments were removed by organised heavy equipment and transported to scrapyards or dumps.http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/25225395.html By February 25, 2014 an estimate ran of over 90 statues and monuments being pulled down, removed or relocated.http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/24/leninopad-falling-lenins-statues-ukraine_n_4847364.htmlhttp://expres.ua/digest/2014/02/24/102431-leninopad-komunistychnogo-vozhdya-zvilneno-vzhe-90-mist-ukrayiny Since February 2014 and mid-April 2015, more than 500 statues of Lenin were dismantled in Ukraine, and nearly 1,700 were still standing.[http://sputniknews.com/europe/20150411/1020751334.html#ixzz3e08kD1yp rasing Own History: Soviet-Era Monuments Torn Down in Ukraine (VIDEO)], [[Sputnik News]] (11 April 2015) * Pulled down: ** [[Kiev]]: a statue of Lenin stood in front of [[Bessarabsky Market]]. It had been erected in 1946. On June 30, 2009, the nose of the statue and part of the left hand were destroyed.[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/16379/ Vandals damage monument to Lenin in downtown Kiev], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (June 30, 2009)[http://photo.unian.net/eng/themes/13469 Photos; Events by themes: In Kiev injured a monument to Lenin], [[UNIAN]] (June 30, 2009)[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-323901.html Monument to Lenin is damaged in Kiev], [[UNIAN]] (July 1, 2009) The statue was restored (at the expense of the Communist Party of Ukraine){{uk icon}} [http://photo.unian.net/ukr/themes/15577 Події за темами: У Києві облили фарбою пам’ятник Леніну під час його відкриття після реставрації], [[UNIAN]] (November 27, 2009) and re-unveiled on November 27, 2009 by [[Petro Symonenko]], leader of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]]. During this ceremony two representatives of [[All-Ukrainian Union "Freedom"|Svoboda]] threw a bottle of red paint at the monument,[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-349133.html Monument to Lenin was opened with scandal], [[UNIAN]] (November 27, 2009[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/city/detail/53774/ Police detain two persons who threw bottle of paint at Lenin monument in Kiev], [[Kyiv Post]] (November 27, 2009) who were then attacked by attending Communists. The [[fall of the monument to Lenin in Kiev]] took place on December 8, 2013.[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/12/08/ukraine-lenin-idUKL6N0JN0IU20131208]http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/wiadomosci/1,114912,15054103,Ukraincy_wciaz_protestuja__Kolejny_dzien_manifestacji.html#MT ** [[Andriyevo-Ivanove]] (Odessa Oblast): Lenin statue was broken in half on January 4, 2014.http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/police-one-more-lenin-statue-broken-in-odesa-region-334671.html ** [[Zhytomyr]] and [[Boyarka]]: Lenin statues were toppled by protesters on February 20, 2014.[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/02/21/7015377/ This night in Ukraine 'Leninopad'], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (February 20, 2014) ** [[Khmelnytskyi, Ukraine|Khmelnytsky]]: Lenin statue was mounted from 1970 to 1992. It was designed by E. Kuntsevych, architects — O. Ihnashchenko, Ye. Perekrest. It has been relocated to the park of Culture and Recreation. On February 21, 2014 it was destroyed.[http://ye.ua/news/news_15327.html Паламарчук В. У парку повалили пам’ятник Леніну (ВІДЕО + ОНОВЛЮЄТЬСЯ) // Є!. - February 21, 2014] ** tens of other locations * Removed: ** [[Kiev]] - on 26 August 1991 the [[Ispolkom|executive committee]] of Kiev voted to remove all the monuments of "Communist heroes" from public places, including the Lenin monument on the central [[October Revolution]] Square (now named [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]] (Independence Square)).[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/1991/359102.shtml Historic vote for independence], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (1 September 1991) **[[Lviv]], the Lenin statue was mounted from 1952 to 1990. It was designed by [[Sergey Merkurov]], architect — I.O.Frantsuz. **[[Dnipropetrovsk]], 2 Lenin monuments were removed by the city in 2014; in March 2014 the city's Lenin Square was renamed "Heroes of Independence Square" in honor of the [[List of people killed during Euromaidan|people killed]] during [[Euromaidan]].[http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/ukraine-day-after_783577.html Ukraine: the Day After][https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/03/14/ukraine-crimea-referendum/6319183/ In East Ukraine, fear of Putin, anger at Kiev] The statue of Lenin on the square was removed.[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/sche-odnogo-lenyna-zvalili-v-dnypropetrovsku-363832.html Пам'ятник Леніну у Дніпропетровську остаточно перетворили в купу каміння "Monument to Lenin in Dnipropetrovsk finally turned into a pile of stones"] In June 2014 another Lenin monument was removed (parts of the monument were moved to a local history museum) and replaced by a monument for the [[Ukrainian military]] fighting against [[Ukrainian Anti-Terrorist Operation|armed insurgents in the]] [[Donbass]] (region of Ukraine)https://sg.news.yahoo.com/video/lenin-statue-toppled-ukrainian-city-164726860.htmlhttp://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/06/27/7030344/ **[[Zaporizhia]] - In March 2016, statues of Lenin, [[Felix Dzerzhinsky]], [[Sergey Kirov]] and a [[Komsomol]] monument were removed or taken down. The statue overlooking the [[Dnieper Hydroelectric Station]] (formerly named Lenin Dam) was the largest remaining Lenin statue in Ukraine.{{cite|title = In pictures: Ukraine removes communist-era symbols|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36396854|publisher = BBC News|author = Vitaly Shevchenko|date = 1 Jun 2016}} **tens of other locations *Relocated: **[[Odessa]], the Lenin statue was mounted in 1967 to 2006. It was designed by [[Matvey Manizer]], О.М.Manizer, architects — I.Ye.Rozin, Yu.S.Lapin, М.М.Volkov. It was relocated to the park of Lenin's Komsomol. **[[Sumy]], the Lenin statue was mounted from 1982 to the early 2000s. It was designed by E.Kuntsevych, architects — O.Zavarov, I.Lanko. It has been relocated to the park at the city limits. **tens of other locations ===Law that outlawed the monuments=== {{main|Decommunization in Ukraine}} On 9 April 2015 the [[Ukrainian parliament]] passed legislation, submitted by the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s” this means that be mid-2015 all communist monuments in Ukraine have to be removed.[http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past], [[Newsweek]], (10 April 2015)[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (9 April 2015) One of the main provisions of the bill was the recognition of the [[Soviet Union]] was "criminal" and one that it "pursued a state terror policy".[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols], [[BBC News]] (14 April 2015) On 15 May 2015 [[President of Ukraine]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the bill into law; starting a six months period for the removal of the communist monuments. In 1991 Ukraine had 5,500 Lenin monuments. By December 2015, 1,300 Lenin monuments were still standing.[http://ukrainianweek.com/Society/154195 Out of Sight], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (28 December 2015) On 16 January 2017 the [[Ukrainian Institute of National Remembrance]] announced that 1,320 Lenin monuments were dismantled during decommunization.{{uk icon}} [http://pda.pravda.com.ua/news/id_7132563 Dekomunizuvaly monuments to Lenin in 1320, Bandera set 4], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (16 January 2017)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.memory.gov.ua/news/z-50-tisyach-pereimenovanikh-obektiv-toponimiki-lishe-34-buli-nazvani-na-chest-banderi WITH 50 THOUSAND RENAMED OBJECTS PLACE NAMES, ONLY 34 ARE NAMED AFTER BANDERA], [[Ukrainian Institute of National Remembrance]] (16 January 2017) ==See also== *[[Fall of the monument to Lenin in Kiev]] *[[List of statues of Vladimir Lenin]] *[[List of statues of Stalin]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Communists monuments and memorials built in the Ukrainian SSR}} *[http://www.monulent.ru/ Monuments of Lenin] * [http://leninstatues.ru/leninopad Leninopad list] * [http://infolight.org.ua/thememap/leninopad Leninopad interactive map] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Ukraine|*]] [[Category:Communism in Ukraine]] [[Category:Lists of public art|Communist]] [[Category:Lists of monuments and memorials]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Vladimir Lenin]]
